newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Netanyahu to testify in corruption investigation.
newsitem.headline: Netanyahu to testify in corruption investigation.

text.p: Israeli police will question Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday about alleged government corruption in the short-lived appointment of an attorney-general, his office said on Monday.
"The prime minister will present testimony tomorrow afternoon," a spokeswoman in his office said.

Police are investigating allegations by Israel Television that Netanyahu's government named Jerusalem lawyer Roni Bar-On attorney-general last month as part of a deal with a politician on trial for corruption.

Bar-On, a veteran activist in Netanyahu's Likud party, quit 12 hours after taking office amid allegations by jurists and politicians that he was a legal lightweight appointed only because of his loyalty to the prime minister.

The television said religious Shas party leader Aryeh Deri demanded Bar-On get the job in exchange for Shas' support for Netanyahu's accord with the PLO on Israeli troop redeployment from the West Bank town of Hebron last month.
It said Bar-On promised Deri a plea-bargain that would have let Deri continue his political career. The cabinet later approved the Hebron deal with Shas's support.
Netanyahu, Deri and Bar-On have all denied the charges.
Police chief Asaf Hefetz said police were ready to question Netanyahu.

"Surely whenever you question any witness, including the prime minister, you have to prepare the investigation, what questions you want to ask, what his connection is to the investigation," Hefetz told Israel Radio.
"They (police investigators) have prepared and are ready for this questioning."

Asked whether the testimony would be taken in one day, Hefetz said: "I hope so but it depends how much time we will have for the investigation. If they need extra time I suppose we will coordinate this with the prime minister's office."
On Monday police questioned Bar-On, not for the first time, and the head of the Israeli Bar, lawyer Dror Hoter-Yishai.

They have already questioned Deri, Finance Minister Dan Meridor, Justice Minister Tzachi Hanegbi, Jerusalem Mayor Ehud Olmert, Deri's former lawyer Dan Avi-Yitzhak, building contractor and Likud backer David Appel, Israel television journalists and others in the case.
